message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest rosacea, a common skin condition, and topical metronidazole is a common treatment option. Topical corticosteroids can actually worsen the condition, and isotretinoin is reserved for severe cases. Topical benzoyl peroxide is used to treat acne, which is not the diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest rosacea, which is characterized by facial redness and telangiectasias. Topical metronidazole is the most appropriate initial treatment for rosacea. Topical corticosteroids can actually worsen the condition, and topical benzoyl peroxide is used for acne vulgaris. Oral isotretinoin is indicated for severe acne vulgaris, but not for rosacea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rosacea, a chronic inflammatory skin disease that affects the central area of the face. Topical metronidazole is the best initial treatment for rosacea. Topical corticosteroids should be avoided, as they can worsen skin thinning and visible blood vessels. Topical benzoyl peroxide is used for acne vulgaris. Oral isotretinoin is used for severe acne and not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest rosacea, and topical metronidazole is the initial treatment option for mild to moderate cases of rosacea. Topical corticosteroids should be used with caution because prolonged use can worsen rosacea symptoms. Topical benzoyl peroxide and oral isotretinoin are used for acne, which the patient does not have.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest rosacea, which is characterized by facial redness, telangiectasias, and papules. Topical metronidazole is the most appropriate initial treatment for rosacea, as it can help reduce inflammation and improve the appearance of the skin. Topical corticosteroids and benzoyl peroxide are not effective for treating rosacea, and oral isotretinoin is reserved for severe cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rosacea, and the most appropriate initial treatment is topical metronidazole. Topical corticosteroids can worsen the condition, topical benzoyl peroxide is used for acne, and oral isotretinoin is used for severe acne.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest rosacea, which is commonly triggered by sun, stress, and alcohol. Topical metronidazole is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate rosacea. Topical corticosteroids may worsen the condition, and topical benzoyl peroxide and oral isotretinoin are not effective for rosacea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest rosacea, which can be aggravated by alcohol consumption, sun exposure, and stress. Topical metronidazole is the most appropriate initial treatment for mild to moderate rosacea. Topical corticosteroids can cause rebound erythema and papule formation, while topical benzoyl peroxide is used for acne vulgaris. Oral isotretinoin is reserved for severe nodular or cystic acne.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rosacea, which is characterized by erythema, telangiectasias, and papules on the central face. Topical metronidazole is an effective initial therapy for rosacea. Topical corticosteroids and benzoyl peroxide are more appropriate for acne vulgaris. Oral isotretinoin is reserved for severe and refractory acne or severe rosacea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest Rosacea, which is commonly treated with topical metronidazole. Topical corticosteroids are not recommended for prolonged use and benzoyl peroxide is mainly used for acne vulgaris. Oral isotretinoin is used for severe acne and is associated with potential serious side effects.
